ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.

ğŸ™ï¸Solid podcast on VC20 with Groq founder Jonathan Ross. He may be a cyborg with LPUs implanted in his brain. A lot of ground was covered including: Big O notation applied to org scaling, Keynesian beauty contests, 7 powers, mopeds and freight trains, hiring for loss bias, financial diabetes, and challenge coins. I rarely re-listen to a podcast, but may be forced to on this one.Â I went old school and took manual notes to sear it into my brain. Hereâ€™s my TL;DR: âœ”ï¸ Plan for Better, Faster, and Cheaper AI: Founders should build with the assumption that AI capabilities will continue improving exponentially. Scaling laws matter more than short-term optimizations.âœ”ï¸ AI Growth Bottlenecks: The three biggest constraints on AI growth: data, algorithms, and compute power. High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) supply is a critical chokepoint, and power availability is the biggest limiting factor.âœ”ï¸ The Inference Wars: NVIDIA dominates training but Groq is leading inference, offering 5x lower cost and 1/3rd the energy per token. The real battlefield is tokens per dollar and tokens per watt, not raw TFLOPs.âœ”ï¸ Datacenters Are Energy, Not Just Real Estate: The AI race isnâ€™t about who has the best chips, but about who controls the power. Inference demand is 20x larger than training, and in 3-4 years, power constraints will slow AI more than chip shortages.âœ”ï¸ AI Business Models Must Optimize for Scale, Not Spend: Startups shouldnâ€™t focus on spending more; they should focus on how much they can scale efficiently. NVIDIA enjoys 70-80% margins, Groq operates at 20% but prioritizes speed and scale.âœ”ï¸ The Big O of Organization scale and hiring: AI startups should scale teams logarithmically, not linearly. If customer growth doubles, you shouldnâ€™t need to double your employees. Use automation to scale. Hire generalists that book the win early (i.e. loss bias).âœ”ï¸ China and Europe: China is winning through brute force deployment of compute, but talent that wants to innovate is likely to leave due to government constraints. Europe lacks an AI â€œSilicon Valleyâ€ due to risk aversion and needs a "Risk-On" enclave to foster AI breakthroughs.âœ”ï¸ The Path to AGI? Solving Hallucinations is critical. Agentic AI (autonomous reasoning systems) comes after this milestone, but hallucination errors must be solved before AI can truly replace high-risk human decision-making.âœ”ï¸ The Economics of AI: More money will be made than incinerated in the long-term. AI is in a Keynesian beauty contest, where marketing and hype matter as much as technology. Most AI startups will fail, but the winners will dominate markets for decades.âœ”ï¸ The Future of AI: The real economic opportunity isnâ€™t in training models but in owning infrastructure, inference, and execution. Prompt engineering will drive the next wave of creativity and business innovation and not constrain extraction of AI value just to engineers.
